newsitem.title: FRANCE: RUGBY UNION-BRIVE TO MEET LEICESTER IN EUROPEAN CUP FINAL.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-BRIVE TO MEET LEICESTER IN EUROPEAN CUP FINAL.

text.p: French club Brive booked their place in the European Cup final against Leicester with a fine 26-11 win over last year's beaten finalists Cardiff on Sunday.

Cardiff, who were hoping to play a second successive final on their home ground, also suffered the ignominy of seeing hooker and Welsh national captain Johnathan Humphreys sent off in the 53rd minute.

Brive, helped by the goalkicking of international centre Christophe Lamaison, scored two tries as they avenged the defeat on Saturday of another French team, the holders Toulouse who were crushed 37-11 at Leicester.

Their victory was amply deserved but it took time to materialise, mostly because of Lamaison's poor kicking during an ill-tempered first half which saw Humphreys and lock Derwyn Jones given the yellow card by Irish referee Brian Stirling.
Lamaison missed with four of his seven attempts at goal but the three others went safely over to give Brive a 9-3 lead at the break.
The frozen pitch did not favour attacking rugby but the losing finalists of last year's French championship tried their luck at running the ball in the second half.
But once again, Brive were too clumsy to convert their domination in points as prop Didier Casadei spilled the ball just short of the line after a furious charge in the 45th minute.
A minute later they got their reward when international centre David Venditti broke away on his own to score the opening try.
Shortly after, centre Sebastien Carrat had the chance to add but, under pressure from veteran Cardiff fly-half Jonathan Davies, he also lost the ball with the line in his sights.

Cardiff's hopes of fighting back took a massive blow in the 53rd minute when Humphreys, after a series of punch-ups, received his marching orders and Jones had to make way for the replacement hooker David Young.
From the scrum which followed, Brive number eight Francois Duboisset crashed over for the second, decisive try.
Cardiff tried desperately to salvage some pride in the dying minutes and were awarded a penalty try in the 70th minute.
The final takes place at Cardiff Arms Park on January 25.
